newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: At least 18 hurt in clash at S.African gold mine.
newsitem.headline: At least 18 hurt in clash at S.African gold mine.

text.p: At least 18 miners were hurt in violence at a gold mine southwest of Johannesburg at the weekend, police said on Sunday.

Twenty-seven men were also arrested during the fighting among workers from two hostel blocks at Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd's East Driefontein mine, a division of Driefontein Consolidated Ltd, on Saturday.
Police said they would be charged with public violence, and would appear in court on Monday.
A revolver, 15 rounds of ammunition and about 500 home-made weapons were seized when police broke up the clash.
Since July, at least 20 miners have died in feuding at Gold Fields' East Driefontein and Kloof Gold Mining Co mines.

Gold Fields has attributed the violence to clashes between members of the 350,000-strong National Union of Mineworkers (NUM), which has a largely Xhosa membership on the mine, and the smaller, Zulu-led United Workers' Union of South Africa (Uwusa).
Production has also been affected by the violence. East Driefontein workers staged a five-day stayaway at the end of August, only returning to work on September 2.
Dries produced 11,680.6 kg of gold in the three months to end-June. Kloof produced 9,877.7 kg of gold in the June quarter.
Labour Minister Tito Mboweni has backed an NUM call for a wide-ranging inquiry into violence in South Africa's mining industry, and plans to ask the cabinet for approval to go ahead.

South Africa's mining industry was built on a labour system whereby men left their wives and families for months at a time to work on the mines. Mine hostels were largely segregated on ethnic lines with Zulus, Xhosas or Basotho in separate quarters.
